awd_titl_txt: Continuous Manufacturing of Anhydrous Metal Sulfide Nanocrystals
awd_abstract_narration:
Metal sulfide nanocrystals have attracted great attention because of their excellent properties and widespread applications in diverse fields including lubrication, optoelectronics, catalysis, biotechnology, and energy storage. Reactive precipitation of nanocrystals is typically accomplished by combining aqueous solutions to create supersaturated mixtures. Such processes are sensitive to processing conditions making the synthesis of anhydrous phase pure materials challenging, in general, and impossible for moisture sensitive alloys. This award supports the study of the manufacture of anhydrous metal sulfide nanoparticles through the reaction of hydrogen sulfide gas with metal-organic precursors in an organic solution. The project addresses the engineering challenges involved in translating this solution-based approach into a scalable nanomanufacturing process. It develops a bubble column reactor platform for continuous manufacturing of the nanocrystals via reactive precipitation. The project targets important materials challenges facing next generation battery technologies. Such a manufacturing capability is critical for enabling widespread deployment of renewable wind- and solar-generated electricity, which greatly impacts the nation's prosperity and infrastructure. This project provides interdisciplinary training for undergraduate and graduate engineers and scientists in energy technology areas. Project results are integrated into the undergraduate curriculum. The building and implementation of the bubble-column platform serves as a module in a unit operations laboratory course.

This project advances a green chemistry approach that results in complete reduction of the hazardous industrial waste gas hydrogen sulfide while generating metal sulfide nanocrystals and recovering valuable hydrogen. The project aims to extract general principles for the design and operation of reactive precipitation processes in bubble columns, including a four-phase design. The research involves demonstrating the ability to control the size and morphology of metal sulfide nanoparticles through rational selection of chemistry (solvent, auxiliary reagent) and systematic manipulation of mass transport parameters. Studies of nanoparticle synthesis under semi-batch operation are used to guide the design and implementation of a continuous manufacturing platform. The structure, properties and performance of the nanoparticles are characterized through the fabrication and evaluation of prototype cathodes and solid-state electrolytes. Continuous production is expected to improve control over nanocrystal shape and size distribution that is critical in the applications of these materials. The combination of gas-phase reactants with organic solutions offers a new paradigm for the reactive precipitation of moisture sensitive nanoparticles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Metal sulfide nanocrystals have attracted great attention because of their excellent properties and widespread applications in diverse fields including lubrication, optoelectronics, catalysis, biotechnology, and energy storage. Specifically, this project focused  alkali metal sulfide (M2S, M = Li, and Na) nanocrystals, which are the critical components and dominant cost drivers for both solid-state electrolytes and cathodes central to next-generation battery technologies for us in lower cost electric vehicles.  Conventional production uses energy intensive carbothermal reduction techniques that provide limited control over size and shape.  In this project we developed low cost, scalable approaches to the production of these materials and validated their performance in battery components including cathodes and solid state electrolytes.

First, we developed a simple dehydration/reduction process to transform low cost sodium sulfide hydrates into anhydrous Na2S. This material was then used as a precursor for the solution based synthesis of solid state electrolytes for sodium ion batteries including Na3SbS4. We developed two routes for the solution based synthesis of lithium sulfide. In the first metallic lithium was dissolved in alcohol and reacted the hydrogen sulfide (H2S), an industrial waste product.  In this process H2S was fully abated and converted into clean burning hydrogen and Li2S.  We developed the ability to control the size and shape of the Li2S nanocrystals which resulted in excellent performance as a cathode and solid state electrolytes.  We developed scalable unit operations for processing including bubble columns and fluidized beds. While successful, the high costs of the metallic lithium precludes the widespread adoption of this technique. Thus, we developed a second route based on the reaction of LiCl with anhydrous Na2S to produce Li2S and NaCl. This reaction proceeds instantly at room temperature and the resulting material was used to produce state-of-the-art argyrodite (Li6PS5Cl) solid state electrolytes.  Having established low cost routes for the synthesis of the key alkali metal sulfides, we then use these as precursors for the synthesis of other metal sulfides such as Sb2S3 and SiS2 in process described as cascaded metathesis. In this process the valuable LiCl precursor is not consumed but recycled in a circular economy.

This award provided support for three PhD students, an MS student, and four undergraduate research experiences. Dr. Yangzhi Zhao earned his PhD thesis in 2019 and is now working for the battery startup Zenlabs. PhD candidates Will Smith and Saeed Vaselabadi are continuing students with expected graduation dates of 12/22 and 6/24, respectively.  Courtney Clark earned an MS degree and joined Los Alamos National Laboratory in 2020. These students published their results in top journals and communicated them at leading scientific conferences. In addition we filed a patent on the cascaded metathesis process. This grant fostered a collaboration with SolidPower, a leading sold state battery manufacturer, for the continued development of these technologies.
